headline.main: Marital Status, the Safety Net and the Recession

docs.abstract: By design, the social safety net does more for unmarried women than for married women, but it may also deter them from seeking employment, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: By design, the social safety net does more for unmarried women than for married women, but it may also deter them from seeking employment, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Shouts and chants for and against the Affordable Care Act turned the block between the steps of the Supreme Court and First Street into a cross section of American politics.

headline.seo: Outside Supreme Court, Crowd Draws Lines on Health Law
headline.main: On Street, Crowd Gives Louder Side of Health Law Argument
headline.print_headline: On Street, Crowd Gives Louder Side Of Argument

docs.abstract: Shouts and chants of people for and against the Affordable Care Act, law being argued in the Supreme Court, turn block between the steps of the court and First Street in Washington, DC, into cross section of American politics; law and challenge to it seem to have prompted bigger thoughts for both sides about a rapidly changing country whose direction is uncertain.
docs.snippet: Shouts and chants for and against the Affordable Care Act turned the block between the steps of the Supreme Court and First Street into a cross section of American politics.

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the Supreme Court will examine how much of the 2010 health care law might survive if the justices strike down the requirement that Americans buy insurance.

headline.seo: Few Contingency Plans if Court Rejects Individual Mandate
headline.main: Contingency Plans Are Few if Court Strikes Down Insurance Requirement
headline.print_headline: Contingency Plans Are Few if Court Strikes Down Insurance Requirement

docs.abstract: Supreme Court is set to examine how much of the 2010 health care law might survive if the justices strike down mandate that Americans buy insurance; next moves by Obama administration and a divided Congress toward finding alternatives to reduce the number of nation's uninsured will depend on how far the court goes, and on the balance of power in Washington after the November elections.
docs.snippet: On Wednesday, the Supreme Court will examine how much of the 2010 health care law might survive if the justices strike down the requirement that Americans buy insurance.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court justices must accept limits on their power and uphold the individual health insurance mandate.
docs.abstract: Editorial holds the Supreme Court faces central test of whether it will recognize limits on its own authority to overturn well-founded acts of Congress when it decides on the constitutionality of the health care law's individual mandate; argues nothing about the mandate falls outside of Congress's clearly delineated powers.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court justices must accept limits on their power and uphold the individual health insurance mandate.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Supreme Court hears arguments on the requirement that most Americans be insured or pay a penalty, Massachusetts offers an example of how such a mandate might work.

headline.seo: Massachusetts Health Insurance Mandate Stirs Dissent
headline.main: In Massachusetts, Insurance Mandate Stirs Some Dissent
headline.print_headline: In Real World, Mandate Stirs Some Dissent

docs.abstract: Massachusetts offers a real-world example of how a law requiring that Americans be insured or pay a penalty might work, even as the constitutionality of such a mandate at the federal level is being considered by the Supreme Court; the state's health officials say that the mandate is working, but polls suggest that although most people like the state law, fewer people support the individual mandate specifically.
docs.snippet: As the Supreme Court hears arguments on the requirement that most Americans be insured or pay a penalty, Massachusetts offers an example of how such a mandate might work.
